#Text=Diego Carrillo de Mendoza , 1st Marquess of Gelves
#Text=Warning :
#Text=Page using Template : Infobox officeholder with unknown parameter " religion " ( this message is shown only in preview ) .

#Text=Don Diego Carrillo de Mendoza y Pimentel , 1st Marquess of Gélves ( Spanish : Diego Pimentel y Toledo , primer marqués de Gélves y conde consorte de Priego , capitán-general de la caballería de Milán , Asistente de Sevilla , caballero de Santiago y comendador de Villanueva de la Fuente ) ( unknown year , Aragon – 1631 ) was a Spanish cavalry general , viceroy of Aragon , and viceroy of New Spain .
#Text=He held the latter position from September 21 , 1621 to January 15 , 1624 or November 1 , 1624 . [ 1 ]
#Text=Early career
#Text=Carrillo de Mendoza was born in Valladolid .
#Text=He joined the army at an early age , where he was distinguished by his energy , valor and intelligence .
#Text=He rose to the rank of cavalry general , and was made lord of the bedchamber for the king .
#Text=He served as viceroy of Aragon before being sent to the Americas .
#Text=Viceroy of New Spain
#Text=Arriving in New Spain in 1621 , he found the administration in a bad state and immediately took steps to improve the moral standards of the functionaries .
#Text=He organized detachments of armed highway patrolmen and assigned them to the principal highways to combat an epidemic of robbery .
#Text=He authorized the immediate hanging of robbers caught in the act .
#Text=He bought grain and distributed it to the poor of the capital and its environs to combat the continuing drought and famine .
#Text=He opposed the monopoly of the grain merchants , formed to drive up prices .
#Text=This made him enemies .
#Text=Also in his first year , he founded a chair of surgery at the University .
#Text=This chair was first occupied by the Mexican-born doctor Cristóbal Hidalgo y Bandabal ( d. 1660 ) .
#Text=On March 7 , 1623 the viceroy ordered work on the drainage system of the Valley of Mexico to cease , because he considered it costly and unlikely to be effective .
#Text=He also ordered the destruction of the dike that diverted the Río Cuautitlán from entering the lakes around Mexico City .
#Text=However , the next rainy season led again to large floods , many lost lives and much damage .
#Text=This caused a considerable loss of the viceroy 's prestige .
#Text=Conflict with the archbishop
#Text=As the result of numerous complaints concerning venality and partiality , Viceroy Carrillo de Mendoza began an investigation of the archbishop of Mexico , Juan Pérez de la Serna .
#Text=The viceroy instructed the archbishop not to grant divorces so readily , not to accept gifts , and not to charge high prices in the butcher shop the archbishop owned .
#Text=This caused animosity between the two , but the final break occurred because of a court case against Melchor Pérez de Veraiz , corregidor of Mexico City .
#Text=Pérez de Veraiz was accused of monopolizing maize and keeping illicit granaries .
#Text=He fled to the convent of Santo Domingo to avoid arrest .
#Text=The judges posted guards around the convent , but the archbishop , invoking ecclesiastical immunity , excommunicated the judges , their clerks and the soldiers .
#Text=The Audiencia appealed to the bishop of Puebla , the apostolic judge in such cases , and he ordered the excommunicated absolved .
#Text=Archbishop Pérez de la Serna responded with a general interdiction , closing all the churches in the capital for some days .
#Text=On January 11 , 1624 , the archbishop in his sedan chair made an appearance at the viceregal palace , in front of an excited crowd .
#Text=Also present was the viceroy , who together with the Audiencia , had determined to depose the archbishop .
#Text=The archbishop responded by excommunicating the viceroy and the members of the Audiencia .

#Text=He reiterated the interdiction and ordered clerics on horseback to ride the streets of the capital shouting " ¡ Viva Cristo ! " and " ¡ Muera el mal gobierno ! " ( " Long live Christ ! " and " Death to bad government ! " ) .
#Text=Thereupon the viceroy arrested the archbishop and ordered him escorted back to Spain .
#Text=Three of the members of the Audiencia revoked the order deposing the archbishop , but the viceroy took prisoners .
#Text=All of this provoked a popular riot on January 15 , 1624 in front of the viceregal palace demanding the resignation of the viceroy .
#Text=The rioters burned part of the palace and invaded part .

#Text=That afternoon Archbishop Pérez , who in the meantime had been allowed to escape , proclaimed Carrillo de Mendoza deposed as viceroy , and nominated Licenciado Pedro Gabiría as captain general .
#Text=That night the viceroy , on the point of being killed by the mob , disguised himself as a servant and fled to the church of San Francisco , where he remained , surrounded by guards . "

column3:
_	_	_	_

#Text=Although the crown briefly reinstated Gelves before replacing him , the marqués was in effect the first Mexican viceroy overthrown by popular revolt .  [ 2 ]
